title: Can I get sued for medical debts?
question: I have medical debts racked up from a car accident in Sept 2009. I had no medical insurance at the time and the auto insurance claimed the accident was my fault. The medical debt is with a collection company and the rep said that I either have to come up with the entire amount at once, they have "started" the judgement process and the only other way to stop it from being filed would be to make $500 payments for the next 14 months, starting next week or else. I can't afford that in anyway shape or form. Can they sue me for the medical debt? and can this turn into my wages being garnished? what can I do?
answers:
Yes, I have represented consumers being sued by physicians and hospitals on unpaid medical bills. I caution consumers AGAINST making any payments, unless they are sure that that they can complete the terms agreed. Otherwise, I don't think it wise to start a payment program now, then be unable to complete it, which may make the problem worse for you. There are statutes of limitation for a debt, and your making a payment will revive the statute of limitations, which discuss in my blog, in the first link, below.

Please also see my three legal guides on Avvo on settling debts and negotiating them. I have the first of this series in the second link, below. If the medical provider or debt collector sues you, you will need to retain an attorney if you cannot afford to settle it, otherwise they can get a wage garnishment, if they succeed in getting a judgment from the court. It will be more costly that way for you, as the judgment would probably be the full amount, plus interest, court costs, and attorney's fees.

My experience is that medical providers tend to use extremely aggressive collectors and actually follow through on their threats to sue. They can sue you for the medical debts and once they obtain judgments, they can start garnishing you. Consult with a local bankruptcy attorney immediately.

Yes, they can sue you for this debt. They will obtain a judgement and then pursue collections from you. You should talk to a bankruptcy attorney and consider a chapter 7 to discharge this and your other debts.

Medical providers often have to sue to get paid, and they usually sue by transferring the claim over to a collection agent of some sort. Owing a doctor or hospital bill is no different than owing any other kind of unsecured debt, such as a credit card, personal loan, or repo fee.

Once a lawsuit is filed, you will have a limited period of time to respond in writing to the lawsuit. if you fail to respond within the time allowed, a judgment will automatically be entered against you. If you do respond, the case may eventually go to trial where a Judge will decide what, if anything, you owe. A judgment typically will include attorney fees, court costs, and interest on the debt.

With a judgment, the creditor will have powerful tools to collect from you, limited only by state laws. They can attach the money in your bank account & yes, they can garnish your wages. Review state laws to find out more about what creditors can & cannot do, or consult with a local attorney.

Hope this perspective helps!
